reviewText:
Hack the Planet!!

I was a fan of Uplink back in the day, but it is certainly time for a modern quality release! I streamed Hacknet for 5 hours the other night and we had a great time experiencing what the world had to offer. You would think I rocketed through the game faster, but honestly much of the time was spent messing around in servers and poking around. The intuitive gameplay, explorable content, and the way the game handles failure made for a really enjoyable experience.

One thing I enjoyed was how intiutive everything was. This isn't linux, this isn't MS-DOS, this isn't even hacking per se. It's an adventure game with a command line interface. Hacking concepts and tools are abstracted for playablilty though it should be noted that there are some real hacking suites out there that are scarily easier to use then what you find in the game.

I'd love to go into details about the exciting things I found, but half of the fun is exploring. One big suggestion I have is to read through the help command in your OS - all 3 pages. Your HacknetOS has a lot of functionality that you wouldn't normally expect. The commands can also let you have a lot of fun! I had a ball changing some IRC logs and websites to include my viewers names to much embarassment and laughs.

An aspect I appreciated is that the punishment for making mistakes is firm but fair. Going into too much detail would be spoiling, but suffice it to say don't just get cozy clicking on the GUI for everything you do. Know your commands and they will treat you well in return.

I did encounter a few minor bugs, some graphic glitches dealing with text, however none were game breaking and I documented this information back to the company. At the stage I'm at in the game there were no hardware upgrades, but I have uncovered a number of hacking tools to provide alternate forms of entry into more difficult servers.

I'm happy to share more of my experience with you, or if you'd like just stop by the channel to see it in action.

DISCLAIMER: I was provided a pre-relase copy of the game by Surprise Attack Games with no additional compensation or influence. Heck I like the game so much I'm picking up a copy to give away to my viewers. :)


EDIT:  After a few more streams of the game, and now about 15 more hours spent with Hacknet I'm still loving the experience  The universe is solid, with some very interesting servers you encounter that make homages to pop culture and game references in some instances.  The banter logs are proabably my favorite things to hunt down as it makes it feel a little more real that people are using these boxes.

As for those miffed about me talking about my stream?  I respect your thumbs down, but potential buyers got to see Hacknet in action and it helped them make a purchasing decision (lots of YES!).  Totally worth it.

reviewText:
Hacknet is a hacking simulation game. You are probably familiar with other games of the same genre, such as Uplink and the Hacker Evolution series. This game is, I dare to say, better than both of those, despite having some bugs.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:Fourteen days after Agent Bit's disappearance, a failsafe sequence was activated. You are one of the only people who can solve Bit's death. As you get more and more involved into the hacker community, you start unveiling a mystery and it's up to you to discover what was really behind Bit and the security system he created.

Pros:    After the success of Uplink, there had to be a game sooner or later that would try to improve what Uplink started. Hacknet not only achieves that, but takes it to the next level. The story alone is amazing and makes sure that you're not just repeating the same commands and actions over and over but gives it a meaning.
I have to say that the whole interface is working really nicely when it comes to clarity and effectiveness. You can do 90% of things both in the Display section and Terminal section, but they are both placed in the interface and I find it surprisingly effective. I use the Display section for figuring out what is going on and the Terminal section to execute commands.
You have a nice map on the bottom of the screen, that is showing all of the cyber locations you have visited already. As you get to connect to tons of computers, you would think that the map would be overcrowded, but this is not the case. I found the map really useful, despite it being almost completely covered.
There is no bouncing from servers as you remember from other hacking games. Instead, traces are lost if you simply disconnect. Even better is the way how the developers managed what happens if you get traced. Your computer (the virtual one, of course) activates a failsafe sequence. It tells you the IP of your ISP and your IP. You have to break into your ISP's server in a very limited amount of time and from there, reset your IP. This is a brilliant way to prevent accidental game overs and having to start all over again. Instead, you are provided with one more hard (and fun) challenge.
I really enjoy the soundtrack in this game. The song was written by a guy who also made the soundtrack for Hotline Miami. The music matches with the tension of your current illegal doings and really makes your heart beat faster. Amazing job.
The in-game hacking is based on actual UNIX commands, which is pretty cool. Still, don't expect to be a pro hacker when you finish this game. You would still be a few steps away, the first step being stopping playing hacking simulators instead of learning the real deal.
There is a ton of Easter Eggs in this game. A clicker game, hidden Steam keys and a lot more. It's really impressive how they manage to fit all sorts of things into this game. Also, you should read all of the IRC chat logs when you encounter them. They can be super funny (and useful).
I have cooperated with the developer in bug-related issues and I have to say that I really like the way that the developer interacts with the community. (Almost) all of the bugs I have encountered were fixed and I'm glad that they managed to bring the final release in a shape that they did.
Another interesting aspect of this game is puzzle solving. You have to think really hard to solve some of them and you even have to remember things from your previous missions, write things down and stuff like that.
If you don't like the user interface, you will encounter skins later in the game that you can download and make your virtual computer looks just the way you want.
The system requirements are low, which is great for old computers. However, there are some moments when FPS suddenly drops and gets to a normal level quickly.
$/€10 is a steal for a game of such quality. If you ever enjoyed hacking games, this should be the top game on your wishlist.
Cons:    Bugs. Many were fixed, but some are still present. The game-breaking ones are gone, however, so you should be fine.
This game should have a button to reset progress. I wanted to do that a couple of times but you can't really do that without browsing through folders and files.
The final verdict:As a big fan of hacking games, I was very happy to be able to play Hacknet. The game is certainly made well and definitely recommend this game to you if you enjoy hacking games as well. The story is surprisingly good and adds an important part to the whole experience. The hacking really feels real and, even though that the commands are pretty much the same through the whole game, never feel repetitive.
This is, no doubt, the best hacking game ever released. Get it, and fast!

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

reviewText:
Hacknet is an absolute gem of a game.

TLDR: While people already familiar with using *nix or general programing principles may find this game not too deep or challenging, it offers a well thought out narrative, with fun game mechanics and excels at teaching you about computer essentials without you even realizing it.


More thoughts:

While this game isn't perfect, I would still reccomend it to anyone who has even a remote interest in computers. Even if you only want to feel like a hacker in a movie, that game gives you that feeling. If you want to learn more about the general concepts of computer-, program-, and network-architecture, this game is a great launching-point, before you start reading more serious" or conventional literature on the subject.

reviewText: Many will claim that this is like playing the next version of Uplink since it is the most realistic hacking type game since Uplink was released. A very cult genre I think with very few games making a significant mark. I cannot claim to have played that classic so I will have to describe this entertaining game called Hacknet without any past comparisons. I will say that the reason it is compared though is because it takes the hacking seriously and isn't just some casual hacking game for the masses.\n\nHacknet has almost no graphics (Maybe about 5 image files in the entire game), it has no video. It is only you looking at a computer screen full of numbers and files. You are a hacker, not Rambo, or James Bond, or Batman. You don't shoot at criminals and punch clowns in the face to save the day. You are a hacker that has found yourself in the middle of some hacking factions that may have stumbled into something big. You get some simple clues at the start that something is going on, but as you delve deeper into the hacking world, get recruited by more skillful hacking groups, and find more mysterious actions going on in your hacking exploits you will get asked to help find out what happened to a popular hacker that has gone missing. Just like everything in the hacking community, all useful information is hidden on systems which need to be hacked into. While looking for that information you will uncover many more secrets as you figure out exactly what happened. A final ending that could be considered a shock". Very intriguing storyline and way to tell a story all through computer documents

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: I was provided a press review copy for the purposes of documenting the game for PCGamingWiki, a publicly-editable technical wiki for games.

What would happen if you gamified the idea that you found a copy of an OS which was so dead-simple to use, anyone with basic computer and investigative skills could hack into anything? You'd get Hacknet, an excellent hacking game designed to be the spiritual successor to Uplink. Slick graphics, a sliding difficulty designed to get you introduced to the game's mechancis one-by-one, and an in-the-background story which is surprisingly pointient and explores not only how insecure computers really are to a dedicated hacker, but the ramifications, both practical and mornal, of an OS designed to hack anything.

TL;DR: It's a short, satisfying hacking game which, despite how complicated it seems at the outset, eases you into its mechanics, world, and story, and gives you the surprising, satisfying feeling of being both a master hacker and Sherlock Holmes at the same time.

Is this Uplink 2.0?For the mandatory Is this Uplink 2.0" part of the review: no. This is not the spiritual successor hardcore fans of Uplink have been looking for because:
You use a 'real' computer with fixed specs

Summary:

A great little hacking game that reminds me heavily of Uplink. It adds a sense of authenticity and realism by using real world tools and commands. There are many secrets to find and it's a fantastic example of attention to detail in game design. A must buy for anyone with a server admin background and those interested in a more realistic approach to hacking in games.

reviewText:
So I heard you like command line interfaces...
Hacknet takes cues from a mix of places, primarily Hacker Evolution and Uplink, creating a blend that can safely be summed up as a hacking puzzle sim. Your job is to utilise the tools you acquire to probe and gain access to a selection of progressively trickier systems and networks, and unravel the story of a hacker who recently deceased in a supposed accident. Initially you're given control of HackNet, a revolutionary OS that makes you essentially invincible from traditional tracing methods, and a few basic tools, from there your job is to gather the resources you'll need to piece together the mystery of what happened.

A lot closer to the real thing than I expected...
Hacknet hews a lot closer to the real nature of exploiting individual ports (even if the programs are automated and require little work to figure out the relevant exploits), and you'll be picking apart servers step by step, usually using command line textual input which makes the game feel" an awful lot more real than say
date: Uplink (though uplink succeeded much more from a neuromancer perspective). You'll be learning the concept of using shells to overwhelm proxies
recommended: cyclical analysis and syndication to deal with firewalls
hoursPlayed: and the use of various tools to pry open specific ports to eventually use your swiss army knife tool "PortHack" which will then turn over Admin control of a system to you. Then you get to explore
voteText: and use various commands to remove evidence of your tomfoolery.\n\nOh Bash
helpfulPercent: you wonderful meme generator...\nThe game is LOADED with internet culture references
votesHelpful: the devs made liberal use of bash.org for IRC logs which litter the servers
votesTotal: taking a "best of" the IRC culture and invariably having some real funnies tucked away on the servers for you to discover
votesFunny: along with various text files with references to games and other internet geekery. There's a lot that's relevant and interesting
commentsCount: and you'll no doubt enjoy what you find as you explore the various servers. There's also hidden paths
column16: servers lying out of the way
column17:
and secret side dishes for those willing to investigate and probe various elements of the games rather cavernous depths.

A stylish presentation
The game is presented in a very slick x-term package
column18: anyone who's used X11 interfaces in Linux will be very much at home here
column19: and more entertainingly
column20: there's the ability to replace your xterm with ones you find
column21: changing up your wallpaper and colour scheme as you progress through the game. The music too
column24: with music that's contextual to various events kicking in and ensuring that you get pumped up at just the right times. Even the HackNet OS boot sequence is pleasingly authentic
column25:
right down to little details such as memory allocations and devices and the like.

Closing thoughts
The one big criticism is that this game is hand crafted
column26: this is both a strength AND a weakness
column28: once you've finished the game and plumbed out all the secrets
column29: there isn't much more to come back to. However
column34: and very nicely presented. Not to mention a great callback to -good- hacking games
column35: which is something that's been sorely missing as of late.\n\nVerdict : Highly recommended"

reviewText:
> UPDATED 16 of August. Check below.

An interesting mix between Uplink and Street Hacker, for the price of ~10 USD is definitely worth checking out.

The game is pretty fun, some things require attention to detail and logical thinking, and the humor is pretty good!

However, the game launched with a very bad bug which might make your save useless: if you try to make two missions at a time, you won't be able to complete the first one. This can simply kill your save.
Also, even though the presentation is well done and the interface looks pretty, I don't see much advance over what other Hacking games did before (Uplink was released in 2001), so you really should approach this with caution. The biggest difference here is being able to use both a GUI and a Console - which is good news.

This doesn't detract from the enjoyment of the game, of course. But it does dissapoint if you expected anything more than that.

I haven't finished the game yet, due to the bug that probably broke my savegame. But about the plot: it's decently intriguing and will make you want to uncover all the secrets, as a hacking game should.

So even though I ended up pretty disappointed - it's 2015, yet there's little news here. Even Street Hacker, which is a decade old and terribly programmed, had deeper features; and Uplink had a more compelling gameplay and story - there's still some fun to be had and some jokes/moments actually made me laugh or smile.
I do recommend waiting for a patch before playing it, though. So rush it on your own risk. :)

Thanks for reading!
-----

UPDATE: As of 16 of August, there has been an update to try and fix some issues. I made a new save and it broke itself again - the game forced me to have two missions at a time, making the first one unable to be complete, which would make it impossible to finish the game.
This release was a REAL mess, and it annoys me that some people are defending the game blindly. After two playthroughs, I was unable to finish it. So please, start taking notes of the facts.

Therefore, I must say that you shouldn't buy this unless you're a fan of the genre - unless all of the gamebreaking and save-corrupting bugs are fixed.
For reference, I'm 98% on the way to giving this a rewrite with a thumbs down.

reviewText:
Final Update (3):
Seeing as the dev doesn't seem to give a damn anymore about providing the patches necessary to have the game work as advertised in a timely manner, I won't check on it or update the review any further.
Maybe the game will someday be what it should've been from day 1, but 3 weeks early access quality for a full release isn't acceptable.

-------------------------------------------------------------

Sadly, this has to be a not recommended review.
The reason for this is the apparent lack of quality control before release. See details below.

First off, the concept is great. I really want to love this game for it's concept. It is basically a much better version of Uplink.
Now, is it realistic from a hacking point of view? No. But that's a good thing, because realistic hacking scenarios would be pretty boring for a game. The concepts are taken from the real world and simplified/modified to make an interesting game.

It is simple at first and doesn't get too difficult while still providing some challenges and a nice storyline.

That being said, while the game could be a 9/10, game-breaking bugs currently make it at most a 4/10.

Here are some that I've encountered so far:
- You are able to take multiple contracts at some point, but doing so will prevent further progression due to the quest completion system being bugged.
- Using multiple profiles is inconsistent, you can't be sure that your savegame remains the way it was
- Game supports windowed mode but crashes regularly if you focus on another window
- Loss of all savegames - this is a big one. The last time the aforementioned crash occured, I've lost all of my saves.

The last bug on this list is the main reason this review has come to a not recommended conclusion and the others severely contributed.
If any beta testing would've been done, such a list of game-breaking bugs wouldn't exist.

Update 1: After the most recent patch promised a solution  to many issues that were causing people to lose save files" I've decided to start a new profile. Did some work
date: saved session and exited the game normally. And alas
recommended: as I started the game again today there were no accounts and my save_accountsMeta.xml was gone. Again. This is clearly getting ridiculous and I wouldn't expect a solution any time soon
hoursPlayed: the dev will probably need a few weeks to figure out the issues with Steam API/Cloud saves etc.\n\nUpdate 2: Since apparently fixing the savegame issues within a reasonable amount of time isn't happening
voteText: I have to say this is close to false advertising. The game should be tagged early access if the amount of issues is still that extensive after two patches. This is the sort of behaviour I'd expect from large companies that simply don't give a sh*t anymore
helpfulPercent: not form an indie dev trying to make his name. I hope the dev learns some things from this failed release

But that doesn't change the fact that as a customer I kinda feel cheated
votesTotal: since there's a reason I don't buy early access and this time the product isn't of higher quality.\nAgain
votesFunny: once the major bugs are fixed and solutions for the existing issues are presented
commentsCount: I'll gladly give this game a recommendation."

reviewText:
First of all, I never played Uplink, so I can't compare this to that. What I did play was the HackRUN saga, so please pardon my comparison to a not very similar game. I also think it's funny that there are .dll and .exe file on what is (seemingly) a Linux system, but I can ignore that.

In a nutshell, Hacknet is a hacking sim game with a decent storyline. That is something I don't see often. HackRUN also has a storyline, but it's pretty linear if you ask me. This game uses real UNIX commands. For those of you new to the coding world (I guess?), it won't be hard to pick up; the tutorial does a good job of introducing the commands, and the 'help' menu will always be there to help you. For those of you who are familiar with the UNIX command prompt, you will be pleasantly surprised. The animations you get when hacking is pretty cool too. The best part of this games\ is that there are some systems that will start tracing you once you start your hacks. You have 100 seconds to do whatever you need to do and GTFO the system, or else (I don't actually know what happens because I have never failed doing so). You can, disconnect midway to cut the trace short and come back in the system again to do your stuff (again) at a later time, but hey, where's the fun in that? Along the way of making yourself a name in the hacking world (in the game), you will encounter files that are seemingly unimportant (like IRC log files, random text files, etc.). You are half right, most of these files are unimportant. They may contain jokes and the stupidity of internet friends chatting together; but the rest may contain passwords that will make your life much easier when attempting to access some systems or useful information on your target's location.

There are decent puzzles in this game that happens in a specific scenario, but the contracts you get are pretty repetitive: probe the system, bypass proxy/firewall if those are there, open some ports, hack in, do your stuff, clear logs, get out. New commands are introduced every now and then, but those have instructions along with them, so it's pretty easy to do whatever you need to do after. Basically, it's not very challenging (unless the devs add a No x-server" mode to force you to use the command prompt throughout the game
recommended: devs pls read). The last thing that this game lacks is the ability to adjust the SFX volume. Me clicking things actually shocks me sometimes because trust me
hoursPlayed: the SFXs are loud.\n\nIn conclusion
voteText: Hacknet is a good hacking sim with a decent storyline and a bit of realism. Would I recommend? Yes. Would I play again? Yes.\n\nIf you reach this point
helpfulPercent: thank you for raking your time to read the massive wall of text that my review is (lol)."

reviewText:
An immersive blend of realistic technologies and concepts used in actual hacking / penetration testing with hollywood esque fancy displays.

I especially love the references to real-world technologies (FTP, SSH, SMTP, Linux commands and utilizes like SCP and CAT, HTML source code, ForkBomb, etc).

If Uplink: Hacker Elite was akin to 1980-1990s era computing environments, Hacknet is to more contemporary computing.

DEFINITELY recommended for any hack sim fan.
voteText: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I have had much, MUCH more fun playing this than I expected.

A combination of a clever plot, interesting puzzles, atmospheric music and a well managed difficulty curve makes it very easy to lose yourself entirely to being the hacker that we all saw in films in the early 2000's.  Only actualy capable of using a computer.

The game starts you off with a straight-forward set of tools, which rapidly expands to meet the various challenges you meet.  By the end, I was utterly enthralled by and immersed in the game.

It's more story based than the obvious comparison, Uplink, so you do less in the way of freelance hacking.  It would have been nice to have the option to be slightly more mercenary, but the story blossoms as you approach the climax of the game - motivating you emotionaly as well as intellectualy to see the game through.

What's more, there are lots of little easter eggs you can find, people's activities you can track and secret activies to uncover - if you know your way around the computer languages the game is built around I have no doubt that there are even more possibilities.  I haven't, but I didn't feel that I was missing anything.

I would seriously reccomend givng this game a go, its been a while since I've played a game that made me feel genuinely clever - neither led-by-the-hand nor over-faced by its challenges.

A very neat trick indeed.
voteText: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
As a lifelong computer geek nerd I have always sucked at coding and command line stuff. Back in school I was bad at languages and good at science, maths and creative stuff so I blame my sucky coding skills on this.

I have however always been a fan of hacking games such as the Uplink and Hacker Evolution series but they have always felt more like hacking from the movie hackers rather than what actual hacking might be like. Hacknet is much closer to what I imagine it is like and I really enjoyed the time I spent with it. The game was easy to get into and moves at a decent pace with an intuitive difficulty curve that meant I never felt I knew exactly what to do but equally never floundered and got stuck.

As far as I understand this isn’t really an accurate sim of any kind of software it is instead an adventure game with a DOS style command line interface. There are some graphical elements to help things along but the game, at least to an outsider, feels very real.

There were a few times that I got stuck but this was nothing that a few moments checking the help page did not fix. If anything one of the things I feel could have really benefitted this game would be multi-monitor support. It was really annoying to have to flick between windows as opposed to having multiple windows open at the same time.

The game is relatively difficult but not unfair but I think someone with a better knowledge of command line interfaces might have found it easier.

As you progress through the game you begin to understand more about the world you live in as the story evolves in front of you. There are a fair amount of pop culture references that always raise a smile.

Overall Hack Net is well worth playing to anyone who watched hackers or Jurassic Park and wanted to feel like they were ♥♥♥♥ hot at computering.

If you have enjoyed this review and found it informative please join our Curator group to get more recommendations http://steamcommunity.com/groups/gametutor#curation

This game is hard to rate,

Actually i would have given a thumbs down because there are many bugs and the game is really repetitive.
You do the same commands over and over again to break into computer and it seemed kinda senseless to continue, because you dont have to think about anything if you get to know your way around. The first hour playing REALLY nice, but then you know your stuff but the game doesnt seem to evolve.

I played 6 hours in the first playthrough, but the actual playtime would have been roughly around 4 hours, if i wouldnt have been distracted. Thats not exactly much for 10 bucks (especially if its repetitive)

However 2 missions (Junebug and final mission) saved it for me and i m glad i did stick around long enough.

reviewText:
This is an OK game. I wouldn't go as far as to compare it to either Uplink or the Street Hacker series simply because it feels more like a demo when compared to them. The execution and gameplay is shallow and naive. It's plagued by many basic design issues and most of the missions are just boring, repetitive, and feel more like a chore rather than a challenge.

My biggest gripes are:
-boring, repetitive and easy missions. Only 2 interesting missions stand out, the final Bit one, and the online pacemaker one.
-no sense of urgency or challenge. If you get caught hacking, that's just a reload to last checkpoint. No point in deleting any logs the way Uplink makes sure that you do. Uplink kept you on your toes because getting caught meant absolute game over!
-Badly designed UI. The workstation map" is a cluttered mess especially as you move closer towards the end. Nodes are being randomly generated and the ones closest to the edge of the screen have their hover information cut off. How that ever went past the testers
hoursPlayed: spelling mistakes
voteText: juvenile jokes scattered here and there. The ending was incredibly cheesy and anti-climactic.\n\nNot a bad game to get on sale. But this is no Uplink for sure. The tagline shouldn't be "if you liked Uplink
helpfulPercent: you'll love this!" It's more the other way around because now I definitely feel like going back and replaying Uplink for the zillionth time! :)"

reviewText: Well, I should probably say that I didn't necessarily expect one of my new favorite games of all time to be an overglorified super-hacker os simulator, but here I am now, I guess. There's so much detail put into this game and it ends up becoming extremely challenging. There's a lot of learning to do in terms of what programs you need to utilize in different situations and generally how to use the interface (especially if you're not too amazingly tech-savvy). I, myself, don't consider myself anywhere near a technological expert, but I was still very easily able to get the hang of it largely due to the intricate way the game was structured and paced. There were so many things that were beautiful about this game, and I admittedly got addicted to this game. It'll probably be a game that I'll often pick back up and play over and over again in the future, and I certainly don't have any complaints in that regard. It may be off limits to people who are easily confused or who tend to give up on things quickly once they become overwhelmed with new information, but otherwise, this game is easily worth over $40. It's $10. Just ♥♥♥♥ing get it.

reviewText:
So I just finished the game.To be honest, I'm not what to think.
First of all, I quite impressed with the amount of detail that was put into it.
On the other hand, it has a lot of missed opportunities when it come to writing, UI-Design and some mechanics.
The (mostly) reallistic terminal commands really help the immersion.

And that's in my opinion the main selling point of this game.
When sitting in a dark room; late at night; typing as fast as I could to avoid being traced;
That really had me at the edge of my seat...  So recommend everyone remotely interested in
real life hacking to give it a look. It's well worth your attention.

Although, I'm not quite sure if it was worth all the time I put into it. (-Clock.exe-)
The storyline is nothing groundbreaking and the writing tends to be dodgy at times. But what really made me stop playing for a while before I finished it: The missions get really repetitive. Mostly, because the different .exe exploits/scripts/hacks don't differ mechanically. It's just type whichever you see fit and wait for it to finish. Which is in my opinion the games biggest flaw. (I'm not sure I'm missing the point because it's supposed to reallistic, but after all, this is a game.)

Which is truly a shame, because these last few missions are really fun.
So if you can keep up the grind, go get and finish this.

Oh, and, I really wish to see a Hacknet 2"."

reviewText:
I normally don't write reviews for games, but this one deserves a good one.

This game is amazing. It gives you a hacking type of feel without shoving advanced commands in your face. Sure, there are commands in this game you should learn, but how you play it is up to you. You could use the GUI, or you could play the whole game using the command line. Its nice that you get a choice, and this is a more modern type of hacking game then Uplink was.

I also love how extensive this game is. If you connect to your own system and run the command openCDTray, your CD drive actually opens up! I wasn't expecting that at all! Another thing, on the bootup screen for the HackNetOS Virtual PC, it actually displays your hard drive name. This game is fun and extensive, and its so cool! What more could you ask for?

If you are a fan of text games, or like adventure games, or liked Uplink, buy this game now. You will love it.

reviewText:
Overview:
Hacknet is at its heart a digital exploration game. Using a powerful suite of programs that you gain throughout the game, the player must gain access to systems and perform contracts. The game has a very similar feeling to the older game Uplink and hacking is done through speed, knowledge of your tools, and system resource management (RAM).

Plot:
The plot is pretty threadbare, but does a good job of pulling the overarching story together. The ending makes sense, but is a little lacklustre for the scope of what you supposedly accomplish. However, this is in character for hacking since public attention is bad for those at the fringe of legality. Overall, I enjoyed the plot, but the beginning intro and ending are really the only interesting points. It's difficult to do characterization when all you have is text, but I felt that more effort could have been put into letting the player get to know more of the other people in the story (naix, maybe some backstory on bit, etc.)

Gameplay:
The gameplay is separated into two parts: hacking and forensics. The actual hacking is rather easy since most trace timers last far more than long enough and some systems actually keep your admin after you disconnect. The main challenge in this format is simply knowing which order to run the port hacking programs in so that you can maximize efficiency and minimize time spent not logged in. These do get quite intense at times and a few conflict sequences definitely run the point home that you're not invulnerable. Progress through the game is blocked in a sort of metroid-vania way, in the sense that you need this power to unlock that type of port to enter. I enjoyed this, but wished that there were more early systems that you needed to backtrack to.

That backtracking is part of the second part of the gameplay, the forensics. By this I mean that you spend your time going through file systems trying to spot the file with the password, scanning computers to reach connected nodes, and searching for new IPs to check out. In fact, there is an entirely alternative gameplay path that is only reached with diligent use of your tools. I loved the exploring, but it did feel quite limited, or at the very least truncated to be more accessable for players who might not be used to the gameplay style.
Part of the joy of the exploration comes from the humor that you find in random files. From a script for Titanic 2" that involves the icebergs running onto land and attacking people to Bash.org IRC logs
date: there is a decent amount of silliness and joy to discover. However
recommended: since the files in the systems you hack are procedurally generated
hoursPlayed:
more content would have been nice. There's only so many times that you can see the same Bash log before you stop wanting
to check them out because you feel you've seen everything.

Pros:
*really fun
*sense of satisfaction from difficult hacks
*humor: From a mission where you need to write "d*cks" on the main webpage of "Nortron Security" to an homage to *chans (the secret /el/ image board)
voteText:
the game is very funny and self aware.
*exploration
*failure penalty fair
*short: Hacknet doesn't wear out its welcome
helpfulPercent:
which it probably would have for some players by the end game.

Cons:
*repetitive
*short
*not enough content
*exploration feels like it was stunted for ease of access

Hopes:
*mods:
I feel that mods could make this from a good game to a great game. I'd love to try my hand at adding new features to the game.
*hardware changes
Uplink let the player purchase hardware upgrades to increase ram or processing power as well as giving access to more complicated systems. Hacknet's only customization for your computer is changing the display theme.
*more story
Getting to know the other hackers more personally would be very enjoyable.
*higher difficulty
clearing the logs on a system means that they won't track you down - but this presents a problem. You always leave a disconnect log
votesHelpful: but the game doesn't notice that a disconnect log without a matching connect log implies\nthat the IP that disconnected was responsible for the attack. Having to selectively clear logs and/or bounce IP like Uplink might be a good idea. In addition
votesTotal:
I would have enjoyed more difficult forensics and encrypted files
that you can't find the password for. I was a little miffed a few times when I spent some time looking through the files to find the next IP when all I had to do was type "scan". More threats to the player as well as uncertainty
in how well you performed the attack would be welcome.
*more challenges
Maybe adding in new network architecture requiring the player to do a different minigame than typing the first two letters of a program and tab completing.
*multiplayer
multiplayer is hinted at being in development in the files on the endgame server.

Bottom Line:
I love this game and want to spend so much more time on it
votesFunny: but sadly it seems that there's no more content. This type of game is sadly lacking in today's market and is quite unique. It pulls off what it does well and with much better guidance than Uplink. You should try it if you're interested in learning basic cmd/*nix commands and command line navigation/use while having fun

reviewText:
Wow! I sat down 4 hours ago and started this game and before I knew it I had blazed through the whole thing.

I'm a big fan of hacking games, especially ones that mix pseudo-realistic stuff with fun Hollywood-style flair. Uplink, released in 2001, is still one of my favorite games because no game before or since really hit that sweet spot. Until Hacknet!

This is a compelling, challenging game with a solid framework of simple mechanics that require you to be ever-more precise and fast in your execution. It also features a number of puzzles that never seem unfair, and yet also never insult your intelligence with hand-holding.

In comparison to Uplink, Hacknet has no RPG elements, for better or worse. I liked doing random missions over and over again in Uplink to grind up cash to buy a faster processor, new software, etc, but I'm sure many people will prefer Hacknet's more direct and explicit design. Actually, the contracts you're sent on don't feel random at all - each one is a unique challenge in some way, and overall the game is far, far less tedious than Uplink.

The story follows a fairly predictable arc, but that's okay. What keeps you playing isn't wondering what will happen next, but what new type of security you'll have to learn to deal with. The flow of new content is paced perfectly. You're not rushed into a bunch of stuff you don't understand, and you're never just killing time.

There are some nitpicks - I think a few of the challenges might overwhelm people that can't or won't use the terminal, and frankly those Bash.org quotes that are everywhere are older than most of the people on Steam.... but this is a fantastic game at a fair price. If you like puzzles, action, and aren't afraid to type out cat irc_chat.txt"
date: then do yourself a favor and pick this up today."

Great hacking game with realistic commands and hacking abilities. Not indepth to scare away people that don't know much about hacking, but enough that people with knowledge about hacking will have an enjoyable experience.

Improvements that could be made:
- Update info: trading cards ARE available for the game
- More quests that chain together, quest lines of getting into hacking groups etc
- Quests that affect the outcome of certain events, decisions on whether to help someone or not etc

Overall fun game, and worth the play. I would recommend this to anyone who asked me if the game was worth buying.

8/10

reviewText:
Hacknet is described as “an immersive, terminal-based hacking simulator” wherein the person playing HacknetSSthe game – you, yourself, sitting at your computer – is the closest thing to a protagonist. It presents you with a Linux-like OS, an electronica soundtrack, and a command prompt. In reality, it isn’t far removed from Kali Linux, a distribution of the open source operating system favored by security professionals and hackers alike.

Most of the game takes place inside that command prompt, where a minimalistic tutorial teaches the player how to list files in a directory, copy and remove files, and run executables. Once the basics are established, the game goes on to provide the player with tidbits of knowledge, such as how to remove traces of your presence on a compromised system, as well as in-game analogues to real-world programs that execute buffer overflow attacks, password cracks, and network mapping.

I would go so far as to recommend Hacknet to anyone interested in network and information security work as a way of gauging their real interest in the field; Hacknet is simply that good.

reviewText:
Buy.

PROs:
+ Theme is captured well; I hope there will be more games like this to come
+ Accessability. I have no recent programming/terminal experience, but was able to easily pick this up
+ Elegant and streamlined interface. Played this on an airplane. Person next to me asked if the reason he got free WiFi from the plane was because I hacked it. - Wasn't a chick to impress
+ A game that left me looking around for similar games to keep the experience going

+/- Story subtlety. I enjoy a story that doesn't throw itself at you like a harlot in heat, but the story could probably be a bit more substantial.

Un-PROs:
- Minor bugs (at least on Mac) with typing in the terminal, like not catching keystrokes or locking on a keystroke, that really suck when you are trying to accomplish a task under pressure
- Linear game: I would have liked to have done all the contracts, but once the game decides it's time for you to move on, then it locks you out of remaining contracts
- Short: I finished the game in 6 hours without using any guides
- Optimization on MAC. This game causes my 2015 MBP to run at 100%, burning the battery at an alarming rate and raising temps uncomfortably high. No reason for a game as simple as this to demand so much from the CPU/GPU.

This game screams sandbox/open world -- a mode where you are left on your own to discover what you need to do and where you need to go, as well as what tools you need to accumulate to accomplish the goal.

reviewText:
First things first:

***I would not recommend this game to anyone that has issues with reading, be it dyslexia, nearsightedness, or just an overall dislike of it because that's pretty much all you will do. ***


Hacknet is a great game for those of us that who grew up watching Hackers. While I can not say if this is a good representation of what it's like to hack a computer (as I have never even explored that avenue outside of trying to break into an ex's email in my youth) I can say that Hacknet is a very good representation of what I would imagine it's like to hack into computers.
The game's strength unfortunately, is also it's weakness.  It feels more real because there is no tutorial other than the information passed on naturally as you progress through the game. However, at times, especially after stopping and coming back to play, you could really use a refresher on what just happened.

My age might have more to do with this than anything else, but I also find it difficult to play long sessions of this game (even though I want to because I want to find out more in the story) my eyes, just get too blurry and tired.
I have yet to finish this game, but I plan on continuing it, just maybe after I look into some new eyes.

Overall: A nice little hacking simulation game that deserves a look over just as long as your eyes are up for the challenge.

If you're still on the fence, I'd say just wait to try it when one of the Steam sales rolls on by.

Thank you for stopping by, have a good day. :)

reviewText:
Amazing game. Definitely feels like a long-due spiritual successor to Uplink. Improves on it in a lot of ways, too; for example, by requiring the player to use a command-line interface rather than just clicking and dragging widgets around. It's also really fun and the soundtrack is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥in'.

Okay, now for the criticisms.

First, the game is way too easy and straightforward. Hacking every system can essentially be boiled down into three steps: take down firewall/proxy, open ports, run magical hacking tool. Missions are similarly straightforward: once you Hack into the Mainframe™ you dig around for clues, and if that fails, use your magical scan tool. Sometimes you're on a timer. And so on.

Second, missions are way too linear and the progression is kinda bugged. You are automatically assigned one mission at any given moment, and canceling it breaks the game by preventing you from proceeding to the next story-important mission. Some missions, e.g. the /el sidequest line, don't even trigger unless you meet some very specific criteria, and you can't backtrack to it later on. And even on the final set of missions, you can't even complete it unless you track down one very specific piece of software from a specific quest line which may or may not be available to you before the story-critical mission is forced upon you.

Third, a lot of hacking is just waiting for your damn magical programs to crack open ports and passwords for you after typing stuff into the command line. Which is boring, especially considering there usually isn't much of a challenge to begin with.

Anyway it's still a good game and I have zero regrets about throwing money at it.

reviewText:
Really enjoyed this game from start to finish.

The difficulty ramps up smoothly.  Basically you need programs to perform 'hacking' tasks and each time you do a mission or two you might find another tool on someone's computer to add to your arsenal.

By the end of it you're flooding proxies while solving firewalls while SSHcracking and a tracer is getting closer and closer to finding your IP.

Get in, do your job, clear your logs, get out without a trace.  Fun concept.

reviewText:
This game was a very pleasant surprise and a great discovery for me.
I'm really interested in programming but I never really searched a game about programming/hacking, I found this one totally by chance and I was far from expecting it to be that great.


The Story
First of all, I didn't even expect a hacking game to have a deep story (or even have one). How wrong I was.
When you launch a game, you start by receiving a message from Bit, telling that he's already dead if you read this, and then asking you some requests.
So you just do what he wants, without really knowing why, but hey, you're doing a dead man's last requests.
After some hacking and deleting stuff, he'll told you that he hasn't the time to learn you more, and that you have to join a small group of hackers.
Then you'll just complete some contracts, eventually acquiring some new hacking tools and learning more on how to hack things, to finally join another group of hackers, but more experienced and related to Bit.
You'll complete some more contracts, until someone contacts you about Bit and his disappearance, asking you to help him to investigate this.

So the game is basically a succession of contracts/missions, but each of them has its short but not uninteresting story.
For example, you'll have to hack the server of a company in order to delete a file they asked a hacker to get, or you'll need to hack a school server to add a degree for someone, hack the personal computer of a scientist to see if he's not working on a personal project, etc ...
Special mention for the Junebug Project (seriously, do that one, because yes, you don't have to do all the contracts to progress in the story).

Also don't forget to read the logs in /home folders, there are a lot of funny hidden things ;)

Gameplay
The game is very pleasant to play and easy to take in hand, but also very fun. Basically, you just run programs to open ports to be able to hack. Of course, there are plenty of other things to do, but I won't tell you everything, otherwise it won't be fun for you :p
So while progressing in the game, you will obtain more tools to be able to hack more sophisticated and protected machines, but the more things you'll have to do, the more time it will take, and sometimes, you don't have time because you're traced, so you have to deal with everything you know to be as fast as possible and to succeed in your mission.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack of this game is really amazing, it can be relaxing when you're doing easy contracts or pressing when you're in a hurry, it adapts very well during the game.
Shout-out for the last mission with this absolute masterpiece from Carpenter Brut : Roller Mobster.
Bit by Chris Larkin is also a very good one, but they all are :p
Also, this soundtrack reminds me a bit the Hotline Miami soundtrack, in the style, and that's a good point for me.


Pros
Very cool and deep story
Pleasant gameplay, plus easy to take in hand
Awesome soundtrack
Interesting contracts/missions

Cons
There are still some bugs, like missions not starting, but it's not frequent (happened to me once)
A little short, but for the price it's ok. You can still start a new game and do the contracts you didn't, plus there's an alternate way to do the game ;)


Really a great revelation for me, one of my favorite game, but you might not like it if you don't like programming at all (or maybe you will like it, just try it out ;).
Buy it with no hesitation, and the soundtrack with it :p
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a long-time linucks fanboi, I really appreciated the amount of care that the dev put into making the 'hacking' experience as true to form as possible while still having enough visual doodads to hold the interests of the more casual among us.

Will this game turn you into an actual hacker?
Absolutely not, but the workflow is more or less similar: scan for vulns, exploit vulns, get admin access, search for interesting bits, scan for connections, delete logs, disco.

The music is very good too.

Speeding through, it took me about five hours to finish the main story, which was pretty intriguing throughout. It's quite possible to miss achievements, which gives the game a bit of replayability. While it's possible to get all of them on a single playthrough, it's highly unlikely without a guide.

Even if you're a complete novice, the game explains how to do enough without you needing to resort to a guide. This is the best way to enjoy the game - its a puzzle game at heart, and you're really stripping away a lot of the enjoyment if you do decide to use a guide on your first go-around.

I really have no negatives to talk about, except one that will mean nothing unless you're a command-line junky already. The game only allows for simple one-off commands, so no redirecting outputs or &&ing commands. Really, this is just a nitpick. Everything else was great.

While I got this on sale, I wouldn't have regretted my purchase had I bought it at full price. I'm glad I gave this game a chance.

reviewText:
Goodness gracious, where do I even start with this game.
I picked this one up a while back, because it was on sale and I didn't have any 'hacking' games in my library. And I certainly have no regrets on picking this up.

Of all the hacking games that I have played (Steam games, flash games, etc.) Hacknet is probably the one that I feel has the most real feeling of any that I've played. Most of the game takes place in a command console, there is very little clicking and primarily the typing of commands. That alone gives it a cool feeling, it's really easy to delve directly into the story and feeling and believe that you really are opening computers and doing missions. The game isn't particularly long, but it does have some replay value, and the hours you do spend on the game feel very worth the price. If it's on sale, I highly recommend picking this up, you won't regret it.

reviewText: Hacknet is an excellent hacking simulator. Its user interface is very convincing and sleek, and there is just enough recognizable computer-jargon to make it somewhat realistic without making it boring or too dense to understand. Using the command terminal is way faster (and way cooler) then just using the GUI and makes you feel like you're the real deal.\n\nDownsides to the game are the occasional spelling mistakes and the lack of explanation at some points in the game. My biggest issue with the game, however, is the complete linearity of the game. It never feels like you're interacting with a bigger world around you, just a pre-determined set of servers you have to hack, which is a shame. If it could be expanded somewhat to include a more dynamic 'internet' for you to explore, and more leeway in how to approach missions, this would've been the new standard in hacking sims. As is, it's a great game, but Uplink still holds the title.

reviewText:
For those who like Uplink this is a welcome treat; A hacking game with more story, a more up to date interface that supports both mouse and keyboard controls, situations where your computer has to reboot in a more realistic manner, different interfaces to work with (just different colors and differently ordered, but still) and more.

What strikes me though, is the lack of depth the actual world has in comparison; Where Uplink had over 300 different systems connected to the internet (some of which were routers or servers with an entire local network behind them to explore), here it is a lot more limited. You also cannot upgrade your hardware, bounce your signal all over the world before hitting your target (goes to trace time), and there is no passive search (that I have noticed) going on on the background, which means that either I'm really carefull in removing my tracers or the police will never actually go looking for you.

It is however, very true to the feel of the game. So if you like your hacking games with old-school typing and none (okay, a little) of that sissy-pants clicking with mice this is definately a recommended title for your library.

Interesting side-note; You get to hack into someone's pacemaker to fullfill his wish of being euthenized. It's stuff like that that bring this game a new moral level.

reviewText: Bought hacknet. Gr8 game. Mom walks in. Thinks Im actaully hacking. Now everyone in my family thinks im hacking into schools and other devices. Ok anyway to the real review this game is a true masterpiece. Personally I'e always found that pretemding to hack into other people and companies was so fun. So finally I found the game. It was everything that I hoped for and more. My favourite mission so far would have to be when I changed the Nortron Security Services title to contain the word ♥♥♥♥♥. Overall this game is amazing and I 100% recommend that you get it. even Im not to good with computers but you will gte the hang of it. There is a tutorial, help pages and if you're still stuck refer to this guide, Hacknet Step-by-Step. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=499723234. (DISCLAIMER IT WAS NOT MADE BY ME, I give full credit to [Cash.net] Gorimaccha. TL;DR (it actually isnt that long but anyway) JUST BUY IT.

This game is very, very good. On the surface it seems like a hacking game somewhat in the style of games like Uplink, but with a huge amount of polish. However, when you actually get in to it, its better described as a really clever puzzle game with a very compelling story, wrapped in a layer of hacking. The music and the visuals are fantastic, the whole package is put together to make it feel less like you're loading up a game from steam, and more like you're logging in to a VM and stepping in to the story.

Prospective buyers need to know that this game requires you to learn and use command line functions in order to do most stuff. It does an adequate job of explaining these to the user, however if I had one criticism it would be in this area.  Had I not had command line experience in the past, I would have found the game much less accessible. I feel the game could have done a better job of introducing these concepts to a command line novice.

With that said, if you like puzzle games, if you like a good mystery, if you have any interest in hacking or computer security, and the idea of a command-line interface doesnt put you off, this game is a must buy.

I was really, really impressed by this game. While incredibly old by this point, I still consider Uplink to be the pinnacle of hacking simulation" games. While other games sometimes offered more technical depth to the hacking procedures than Uplink
date: they didn't manage to immerse you in the story like Uplink did. They didn't make me disconnect from the internet out of paranoia like the first time I played Uplink. And while I can't say that Hacknet made me disconnect from the internet (mostly due to knowledge and experience gained over the past 14 years)

Linux was such a clear choice for this, great job!
Though I think they should have built in a real terminal with a modified kernel, or at the least given us [vi] and [mkdir] for organizational and informational purposes. Anyone that has messed with linux will fall right into this, it fits like a glove.

The one thing though that they should have done better was the netMap. It's slightly too cumbersome and nodes on the side have their tooltips clipped. A tree view would have been entirely sufficient; or at least some way to organize it in terms of what you want to see rather than all posssible nodes visible at once.

Great job. Looking forward to your next release.

reviewText: Awesome game! You are not actively modifying code like in Hack 'n Slash. Rather, you are typing in prompts within a command box in order to execute files/commands. You are also able to navigate using a point and click UI instead of having to type commands for every action you want to execute; however, commands are your best friend in this game.\n\nOverall, if Watch_Dogs left you wanting more detailed hacking game play, then this will easily fill that void.
This is just a mindblowingly awesome game. Cross your basic terminal commands with a bit of click this button to hack" and you have a fun puzzle game with a bit of an interesting story."

BLUF:  I was impressed and pleased by the game and recommend everyone to try, even if just for the Steam refund period.  You'll know by then if you like it.

FULL:  This is a solid game that is easily worth the purchase price.  If you are interested in Dilbert comics, you will probably enjoy the humour in this game.  If you are interested in networking, you will probably appreciate the toned-down technical aspects of this game.  If you are a lazy person who collapses under pressure and hates to read... you might want to move on.

I personally find the game acts as a refresher of sorts for the basic CMDs that we tend to forget in this GUI heavy age.  Yes, you may run into grammar and spelling errors throughout the playtime -but honestly, I feel that the communications that occur in this game, the ones you pick thru and piece together over several nodes, could actually take place.  The humanity in the conversations is there, errors and all, and I believe this is what draws the player in.  You do not lose complete focus on what you are meant to do, as much of your play circles around and ties upon itself.  If your current mission is not directly related to the main story, it is training for the next leg that will be taking place shortly. And there are actually very different ways to accomplish tasks!  Do you  delete and replace a file?  Rename it?  download it, modify, and reupload?  Which group/faction" do you really want to participate with?  Did you fully explore all those IP addresses in the emails?  Gahh... I need to go back and play thru again!"

reviewText: This is one of those immersive, what-if titles that makes you type console commands to beat the game.  You're helping a variety of hacker agencies with a variety of hacker missions via your not-so-trusty hacker computer.  The overall experience involves a lot of repetitive clicking of generic hacker 'tools' that do all the dirty work for you.  That said, the game can help you learn about navigating folder structures via the command line, and there are some oh ♥♥♥♥" moments when you think you may have and probably will have screwed yourself."

Great game, highly recommended.  Probably my favorite hacking adventure title.  It's not terribly long (though I'm not sure my recorded play time is entirely accurate), but it's well assembled and tells a good story in an immersive way (read: a lot of reading other people's emails and private files).\n\nOne of the missions called Project Junebug is probably my favorite experience in a hacking game.  I won't go into spoiler-y details, but be sure to play that one as soon as you get there.  I think it's required, but if not, be sure to take it.  Anyway, it's a great game for a fair price from a small developer.  Go get it!

Things you need to know if you are considering buying this:
1) Do It
2) If you like Uplink, this is similar to it but much better since you can never really lose your progress
3) It has a very rich story even if it is mostly text based
4) Has a sense of accuracy to the game in that you can (if you wanted) only use the command line since it is a UNIX based command line
5) Even though the game is short, it is totally worth the money you spend.
6) The community is amazing: if you look up a question you have to a mission, no one will straight up give you the answer you're looking for but instead tell you how to get where you need to go. Very very supportive community.
7) Makes you feel like a real hacker.

TL;DR: BUY THE DAMN GUY. DEFINITLEY IN TOP 5 FAVORITE GAMES.

reviewText: A little bit Buggy but an amazing experience overall

Bought it at release time and played the hell out of it until now. I was a HUGE fan of Uplink, well, I STILL am, as well as Hacknet when it was just a 20 minute long demo on indiedb. This game: totally worth the $8.79. I would've even paid the full $10.99 for this. The UNIX-styled interface, while not really hacking per say, is a really great game mechanic and highly enjoyable. But holy buh-jesus that CCHacker node. 10/10 would never hack it again.

Good Story (4/5)
Great Gameplay (4.5/5)

100% Replayability

Overall (9.5/10)
Hope there's a multiplayer mode getting incorporated!

P.S.  YOU NEED SHELLS FOR THE FINAL HACK AND REALLY QUICK FINGERS - Oh, and don't disconnect, you have to redo the whole thing!

Hits a really good balance between the tedious busywork of Uplink and the clickety-click oversimplification of Hacker Evolution Duality. While this game doesn't depict hacking realistically, it does present a series of pretty entertaining puzzles and tons of not only flavor text, but also side activities with a few nuggets of cool hidden content. It may sound stupid, but it reminded me of that really gimmicky and ultimately pretty useless Enter the Matrix minigame (that I *loved*), only properly turned into a 10 hour game. reviewText: Thoroughly enjoyed this game!  Challenges, surprises, running out of time, running out of ideas, running from the trace!   Reminded me of days at NASA in the 70's when everyone was hooking up DEC PDP 11 minis to DARPANet without changing the default admin and maint passwords.  When DEC Solutions appeared as a hack target I cracked up.  This game was a whole bunch of fun and humor.  I'll buy and play anything these guys come up with from now on.

A unique and enthralling hacking game with a great soundtrack and an undeniable style. The game offers an enjoyable facsimile of hacking that doesn't require any genuine technical knowhow and becomes quite satisfying as the player adapts to the intricacies of the systems and begins to feel more confident as a hacker.

To be honest I don't care waht anybody says I love this game soooo much.\nIt's tense action packed and you never get bored.\nI hope you buy this game even if you dont intend to play it, the dev's done an excellent job.

reviewText:
Total play time for me was around 5.5 hours for the story.

It's very enjoyable and as many have said it's like a mondern version of uplink though I do feel it's not as vast or open as uplink. Don't expect to be upgrading hardware or software, or any kind of money as it's more linear than that. Sadly without money there's no kind of bank hacking which was so fun in Uplink.

Anyway I still recommend it especially at it's low price.
Amazing story, soundtrack, game mechanics and just about everything about it.

Hands down one of the most unique games I've ever played. The music selection along with it makes playing the game feel so good.\n\nIf you have some familiarity with Unix and Unix-like OSes, give this game a try. Definitely worth every minute of playing it.
Great game, good puzzles and intriguing story. Would have like more depth and freedom, but for the price it's great. Also has a good amount of easter eggs and the alternate route is nice.

Hacking sim genre is not getting enough love, and this is the fresh breath it needed. Even though the game still has some bugs, it is definitely worth checking out (the updates are coming).

It's a hacking sim ala Uplink or Hacker series. It is using the stylized interface, but at the same time asks the user to learn to use a command line too. Those, who have worked on Linux will feel almost at home. You have to be careful about your actions but at the same time should be curious and attentive. There are hidden secrets to be found. You can easily lock yourself from progressing by deleting a file that seems unnecessary now, but will be later. You can kill off your own system if you're not careful. It puts all the power in your hands, you take the blame for your faults.

Storyline was intriguing and scaringly possible in reality. From start to end it was an extremely enjoyable experience. Even though a notes system is in place, you should take out your notebook because you will need it.

A simple yet very interesting terminal based game, my father walked in one me once and gave me a speech about hacking is illegal and what not, I actually played along with him and he now believes he's living under the same roof as a hacker.
Epic game! 10/10\nReminds me of uplink, great days.

Wow, Hacknet is one immersive command line game.
You get to pick up the left overs of a now dead hacker, following in his footsteps, slowly taking on harder challenges and making a name for yourself.
Hacknet offers a tight narrative (which is completely text based) and enthralling 'hacking'

Pros:
- presentation. I know a lot of people will be turned off by a CL interface game. but heck (huehue), it's beautiful, intuitive and well designed. plus you can download more UIs from servers and people you hacked
- gameplay. it's relatively easy, requiring (so far, I'm roughly 4 hours into the game) simple management skills, a keen eye and some reading and prioritizing. the hacking is served well, not letting you button mash, but rather focused on the finer points such as: reading emails for usernames and passwords, changing websites headers into vulgarities, finding the right tools and balance, covering your tracks.
a lot of the gameplay is indeed done over a command line interface, which, exactly, means you type out what you wanna do. there's helps, and little tools making it a lot easier than real life hacking could ever be.
- Story. it's a pretty cool mix of paranoia, technology and a weird form of justice. no one talks, no fancy cutscenes. it's all in your head, buddy
- immersion. yeah, the computers you hack are rather empty, but what is on there is hilarious and often gives small hints to connections between the hackers you 'meet' (I think, at least
- music. absolutely perfect.

Cons:
- uhm, let me think ... hmmm ... no, it is exactly what it says it is. and then some

Verdict:

You like hacking/hacking movies or just recently discovered Mr Robot or the deep web?
Well, come on in. this is a perfect supplement to your diet.
Hacknet is pretty (for CL standards :D as I work in IT I actually find it gorgeous), fun and fast paced. It will test your patience, but mostly your ability to read and type properly.
But nothing is keeping it from delivering the best hacker game since Uplink, if not even a tick better.
And it is totally worth the price tag

Pretty cool, I played Uplink way back and the game was awesome you could upgrade your pc etc....


This title is quite the same rinse, repeat 100's of time and apply different exploit technique which is cool. Beside completing missions you can go about sniffing other computers and steal some nice wallpapers....ye!! BUT you CANTupgrade your pc.

I would expect to be able to purchase, upgrade my pc and take advantage of more powerful components. I understand that the scenarios are limited to hacking but there could be lots of potential to this title.

This was an asbolute gem. I love this game. I was actually planning to make one like this myself at one point, but work/life changed that.

Linux was such a clear choice for this, great job!
Though I think they should have built in a real terminal with a modified kernel, or at the least given us [vi] and [mkdir] for organizational and informational purposes. Anyone that has messed with linux will fall right into this, it fits like a glove.
Well made game, I'm still diving into the rabbit hole" to see what other goodies this game has within it. So far I am highly impressed.

The one thing though that they should have done better was the netMap. It's slightly too cumbersome and nodes on the side have their tooltips clipped. A tree view would have been entirely sufficient; or at least some way to organize it in terms of what you want to see rather than all posssible nodes visible at once.

Great job. Looking forward to your next release.
I would pay $9.99 for this 10 times over without hesitance. Going to buy it for my brother who's wanting to learn programming this year."

When I bought this game , I was concerned that it was going to be boring and I would have to utilize that steam refund service again. After completing the game, it has quickly become one of my personal favorite singleplayer games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. The game itself is basically a hacking simulator, but with an incredible story and a plethora of unique files that you find throughout said story which serve to aid in your hacking abilities. I never write reviews for games, but I really felt after playing this one that I needed to do the creator a favor and give him one more positive review.

Of course, this game doesn't have much in common with real hacking, it's just an arcade simulating certain network hacking aspects. I can't understand people who wanted something more. What did you expect to see?

As for me, it's a good puzzle with well-elaborated story (and Linux terminal basics guide, too). One of the best indie games I have ever played.

10 immortal Bits out of 10.

When DEC Solutions appeared as a hack target I cracked up.  This game was a whole bunch of fun and humor.  I'll buy and play anything these guys come up with from now on.

Awesome game! You are not actively modifying code like in Hack 'n Slash. Rather, you are typing in prompts within a command box in order to execute files/commands. You are also able to navigate using a point and click UI instead of having to type commands for every action you want to execute; however, commands are your best friend in this game.\n\nOverall, if Watch_Dogs left you wanting more detailed hacking game play, then this will easily fill that void.

Great job. Looking forward to your next release.

reviewText:
BLUF:  I was impressed and pleased by the game and recommend everyone to try, even if just for the Steam refund period.  You'll know by then if you like it.

FULL:  This is a solid game that is easily worth the purchase price.  If you are interested in Dilbert comics, you will probably enjoy the humour in this game.  If you are interested in networking, you will probably appreciate the toned-down technical aspects of this game.  If you are a lazy person who collapses under pressure and hates to read... you might want to move on.

I personally find the game acts as a refresher of sorts for the basic CMDs that we tend to forget in this GUI heavy age.  Yes, you may run into grammar and spelling errors throughout the playtime -but honestly, I feel that the communications that occur in this game, the ones you pick thru and piece together over several nodes, could actually take place.  The humanity in the conversations is there, errors and all, and I believe this is what draws the player in.  You do not lose complete focus on what you are meant to do, as much of your play circles around and ties upon itself.  If your current mission is not directly related to the main story, it is training for the next leg that will be taking place shortly. And there are actually very different ways to accomplish tasks!  Do you  delete and replace a file?  Rename it?  download it, modify, and reupload?  Which group/faction" do you really want to participate with?  Did you fully explore all those IP addresses in the emails?  Gahh... I need to go back and play thru again!"

Operation Swordfish Activated !!

Hacknet: The Best of It's GenreTLDR at bottomJust to preface this review, I am an avid Linux user and only have Windows installed on my gaming PC because AAA developers haven't found Linux yet. I have been running Archlinux with the i3 window manager for about a year now. People who aren't used to terminal interactions or problem solving in a terminal enviroment may not enjoy this game as much as I have.

That being said, this game is just fantastic, and surprisingly immersive. The first time I was hacked and my game bluescreened, I actually jumped. When it threw me into a failing boot, and then into a framebuffer terminal, and spit out errors about missing my x-server.sys file, I had flashbacks to similar issues happening on this exact PC not more than a year ago. It didn't just look like linux problem solving, it felt like linux problem solving. For a game that uses mainly a terminal, it is extremely immersive.

The problem solving in the game is just superb, when dealing with a traced connection, you genuinely feel under pressure to complete what you are doing, and although earlier systems feel quite repetetive, the later opponents feel challenging and complex. Managing your system's RAM usage, watching the trace, and frantically looking through the files on a system through a traced connection, one of the best feelings in gaming from 2015.

Heck, even the visuals in this game are quite impressive, and surprisingly customizeable. You can actually obtain entirely new x-server.sys files, just by scp'ing (secure copying) them off of systems that you hack, and you can start. It's actually something you could go through the whole game without ever being aware of. BEWARE: FIRST TIME HACKED SPOILER the first time you are hacked in the game, likely from a guy going by the username 'Naix' after messing with some of his stuff, your screen goes black and then opens an all too terrifying screen for any Windows user. The Bluescreen of Death. The PC then reboots, and fails to find your x-server.sys because that asshat 'Naix' deleted it. You then need to obtain another from another server, which you can find the IP for in your log files. I was surprised when I booted that I was actually met with another 'window manager' (or at-least another theme).

I can't quite comment on the quality of the game's soundtrack all that well, as when I play this, I blast my 'Coding' playlist in Spotify, but from what I was hearing between my songs, the soundtrack seems quite nice, although a bit too 'techno' for my tastes. It also seems to entirely lack vocals in any of it's songs, which is understandable.

Reccomendations to the DevelopersSo, here I will leave suggestions I feel the developers could (and should) implement to even further improve their already fantastic game.

1: Control+Key keybindings commonly found in linux terminals would be an amazing addition. For example, I've played the game for 3 hours, but still press Ctrl+L when I want to clear the screen, or Ctrl+C when I want to stop my current command, like rm log/*".

2:Ability to further customize your x-server setup would be nice
date: like the ability to move the Windows
recommended: instead of locking them to where they are defined for the x-server.sys currently used. Not a very required feature
hoursPlayed: but would be hell'a cool :)\n\n3: Maybe make the window showing all the currently known servers just a little bit larger
voteText:
as it gets crowded on resolutions lower than 1920x1080p.

TL;DR:PROS:
+Extremely immersive gameplay
+Later gameplay is quite open
votesTotal: although Linux users will find many similar commands and behaviors.\n+Good soundtrack (from what I've heard)\n+More addictive than crack-cocaine
votesFunny:
and (probably) safer than it too!

CONS:
-Kind of slow game intro (first 30min to 45min is sort of linear and not very open)
-For users who have never even opened a terminal before

column16: the game might have a slightly difficult learning curve
column17:

All this being said

reviewText: Would easily pay 3 times the price! Hacknet gave me a great experience! The game let's you explore network systems by utilizing a variety of tools to crack systems, files, explore networks. There's ALWAYS something new to discover and you will always have many questions, and a corresponding huge urge to discover the answers. You exploit system flaws while looking for human error all while following a very mystical and wellmade storyline that gives the game a touch of crime roman feeling to it. It's always something new around the next corner and it never gets boring. You got quite good control over the pace of the game and there's always a variety of things to choose from. The game ha a great level of detail added, that any computer geek playing it will relate to and appreciate. The game has a great way of swapping the pace and you while you can mostly take your time, you will also be put to the test.
