reviewText:
This game.

This game isn't like most hacking simulators. While it certainly bears a lot of similarities to Uplink, the two games are quite different under the surface. Where Uplink is a sandbox, where the net is your playground, Hacknet is a more focused, and much deeper experience.

It is essentially a text based adventure game, but instead of typing actions your character does, you type commands into the console to hack stuff. It's intuitive and very fun to use once you get the hang of it, and the game does a good job of making you use it in intuitive and challenging ways.

The game also has a more graphic interface (which can be customised with various skins, once you learn how), and some things are only possible through using that, but I'd very much recommend you get used to the console command (trust me, you'll need them).

So what's the game about? To put it simply, it's about following a trail of websites and databases to uncover a mystery; you do this by compromising various systems through a robust hacking system and doing contracts for various hacker groups. It's not just about hacking, though, as you'll then have to search through the system's files to accomplish what you came for, whether it's deleting or editing a file, crashing a website, or browsing through the user's mails and documents to find a clue or a loophole through a heavily defended system. It's very fun and just as much a test of your deductive abilities as your hacking skills. The final mission especially left me stumped and unable to progress, until I realized I could use a technique that I had learned at the start of the game to find a loophole and break through.

But what really sold this game for me was the atmosphere and the story. The game does a really good job of making you feel immersed in the role of a hacker, and I could feel my heart pounding when I disconnected from a system a split second before getting traced, or when I had to hack into my ISP to change my IP-address before I got discovered. You feel like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ badass when you manage to breach a difficult system, or when you engage in some sweet revenge on a rival hacker. The game also left me agonizing over choices that I barely would have given a thought in other games (Two words: Project Juneburg).

The story is very well done. While it borrows some themes from Uplink, it executes them very well, and I may have felled a little tear at the ending.

All in all, if you like any of the things I mentioned, you should definitely give this game a try. This was probably one of my favorite games of 2015, and it's well worth the money.

reviewText:
This is a good game, I would definitely recommend it for those who love hacking simulator games like Uplink and Slavehack.

That being said though, the game is short and entirely story driven, it has very little replayability and very little random content, it also lacks a lot of features that Uplink and Slavehack has, but the features it does have are mostly done well.
The story is interesting enough to keep you playing through it.

As you play through it, you will definitely be left wanting a lot more if you played either of the above mentioned games.

A lot of this might sound negative in a way, but that's only because we all wish for a much more advanced hacking simulator game that have all the features of these games, along with a lot of user suggested features that never got added to any of them. In a way my negative points are only because of the features one would expect from it are lacking.
(Someone make a fantastic moddable hacking simulator game please!)

Again, it's still a good game, so go buy it and play through it.

reviewText:
The game seemed to have a lot of potential at the start, but it didn't exactly deliver the goods.  The gameplay is repetitive and simplistic to put it mildly, the puzzles are absurdly easy (difficulty for me mostly came from occasionally forgetting to run the 'scan' command), and as a whole it doesn't seem quite *finished*.

The various servers and other devices are populated mostly with a few relevant files, a lot of unreadable binaries that seems like they should be relevant but turn out to be just filler, and a huge number of bash.org quotes (some of which are hilarious) sprinkled among /home/NewDirectory${x} directories.  There's little meaningful variation and it's pretty simple to find almost anything you're looking for if it's there.

The story is not terrible, but it's not particularly original or interesting either.

For the amount of time you spend using the command shell, you'd think it would be a bit more polished, e.g. the fact that commands like  'rm *' work while 'rm AccountInfo*' do not, or the existence of an 'scp' command but not just 'cp'.  The UI is kludgy and has a few interesting bugs, e.g. the file system interface fails to change directories properly if you're more than one level deep, e.g. from /home/stash to /log.  My favorite thing though is when I deleted a few files in /sys (for fun), rebooted, and was left with no (obvious) way to quit the freaking game until I fixed things sufficiently to be able to click the exit button.  Really.

The process of actually breaking into a server consists of running a series of magical programs to bypass one or more defenses, open a certain number of ports, and ultimately get admin access; there are a few hiccups with this process, but the vast majority of the time it's exactly the same.  If you see a new type of port, you find yourself often saying I guess I need another magical program to crack this port...oh hey
date: the plot has delivered it right on schedule
recommended: great." or "I don't have a magical program for this yet. Wait
hoursPlayed:
here's a new program conveniently nestled among the vast array of bash.org quotes...again."

I could go on...
If you have to choose between this and Uplink
voteText: the latter (despite its shortcomings) is a far better game.  If you're an Uplink fan
helpfulPercent: you'll likely be disappointed.  With more development
votesHelpful:
I think this game could eventually equal or surpass Uplink...alas.


"

reviewText: Hacknet is a fun, lightweight, educational game for teaching shell commands. Playing the game will enable you to easily navigate through directories and perform tasks like copying or deleting files and so on. It superficially covers the themes of hacking and how hackers interact with a network in an extremely simplistic but accessible way. This is not a study-sim for hacking but you will have a general idea of what hackers do and some of what the terms they use mean. I think this would be a useful tool for kids who want to learn how to interact with their computer without a graphical user interface. But it also presents as a great bit of practice for adults who wish to refresh their memory or teach themselves how to use the command line interface.\n\nI'd love to see this game expanded in complexity. There's a lot of fertile ground here for an amazing sequel for an already great game. The story line is also really clever and feels like a story from a good mystery novel.

reviewText: Wow. I was searching on steam for games that looked good, when I saw this game. A few days later, I bought it and I'm glad I did! This game surprised me, I wasn't really expecting much, but got a lot more than I expected. Hacknet is a game where you must help a guy named Bit that teaches you how to hack, (Along with some other people) and the only thing he wants is for you to find him. Not going to spoil much, but the amount of freedom in this game is huge. From invading other people's conversation, to changing the game's version of KFC's website from saying Everyone loves chicken

Also, you better type fast, otherwise this game will be a bit harder. One last thing I must mention, is the missions do get quite repetitive at times, but the amount of freedom in them helps. So do I recommend Hacknet? Of course, Hacknet's a great hacking game that I recommend to a lot of people. So get it, NOW!

reviewText:
Graphics: Glorious SSH terminal windows
Audio:  Beep Bloop Beep
Music:  Even though the music does change up a bit, more variation would have been nice.
Controls:  Work as expected, except esc key which does nothing.
Mechanics:  The connection map feels sloppy compared to how perfectly the rest of terminal emulation works.
Story:  Take down the evil corporation!  Plus some side stories and random tidbits to be found.
Entertainment:  Would have paid twice as much.
Difficulty: This game would be very challenging for peeps who have never touched a command prompt. For the rest of us this game is no harder than breathing.
Replayability: Depends on if you are clever enough to find all secrets the first time through.
Bonus Point:  Dev followed through and fixed game breaking bugs. GG dev.

reviewText: When I play this game I can't help but feel nostalgia for the game Uplink.  This game is very much a hat tip to Uplink and the developer did a good job capturing the same atmosphere and attraction of Uplink without being a copy cat.  Although comparisons can be made to Uplink, the game definitely has its own voice with a mix of both commandline simulation and minimalist UI.  I've only played for a short time but it has already become one of my favorite games.  The visuals are minimalist but they're more than enough to engage you.  Add in the catchy music and compelling story and you're in for an amazing experience.\n\nWith a plethora of survival games out there its very refreshing to find a game without those elements and instead focuses on a deep storyline.  Don't miss out on this great game, its totally worth full price.

reviewText: Wow. I was searching on steam for games that looked good, when I saw this game. A few days later, I bought it and I'm glad I did! This game surprised me, I wasn't really expecting much, but got a lot more than I expected. Hacknet is a game where you must help a guy named Bit that teaches you how to hack, (Along with some other people) and the only thing he wants is for you to find him. Not going to spoil much, but the amount of freedom in this game is huge. From invading other people's conversation, to changing the game's version of KFC's website from saying Everyone loves chicken
recommended: there's a lot of freedom in Hacknet. One thing I must say, is that you must memorize a few commands in the game, otherwise you'll be going back a lot to relearn some things. Also, you better type fast, otherwise this game will be a bit harder. One last thing I must mention, is the missions do get quite repetitive at times, but the amount of freedom in them helps. So do I recommend Hacknet? Of course, Hacknet's a great hacking game that I recommend to a lot of people. So get it, NOW!

reviewText: Pains me to give this a thumbs down and i'll reverse this when it  gets suitably patched. Theres just too many bugs right now... too many different kinds of bugs. Iv had problems loading saves, problems with quests triggering right and becoming uncompletable, and weird stuff like disconnecting from a terminal mid-hack sometimes results in auto admin access.\nIts too much for me to comfortably continue. Otherwise its a cool story-driven concept and its a fun game that makes you feel like youre hacking. I also wish the command prompt had more commands and a text editor would be extremely nice. (in order to change a file at all you have to manually target each piece of text youre changing with a command).\nFor now id say proceed with caution (but eventually, you should proceed).

reviewText: Uplink: Hacker Elite" was a fun game because it insulated the gamer from the tedium of command-line driven hacking. Hacknet attempts to do the complete opposite
date: by adding in copious amounts of esoteric Unix commands.\n\nI only played the game for an hour before applying for a refund. The in-game emails that I read were mundane
recommended: as though this game was aimed at juvenile highschoolers ( I'm 40 years old ). One email was about a high school kid making out with a girl and prematurely ejaculating in his pants. Another email was a kid talking about the latest "Call of Soldier" game.\n\nI had to do Google searches
hoursPlayed: to find out how to hack a firewall and basically gave up trying to figure out how to flood a proxy server.\n\nI dropped out of programming school in real life. Programming & hacking can be quite tedious
voteText: which is why Hollywood and Uplink: Hacker Elite try and insulate the user from the realities of hacking.\n\nI'd also like to point out that Uplink featured permadeath... which is where a lot of the tension came from."

I saw Hacknet at PAX 2015 in Melbourne, and though I was not fortunate enough to meet the developer, I did get to watch a few people play it through the crowds - and that was enough to intrigue me.

I'm very glad it did, too. Hacknet is an extremely fun little game, with an engaging story and enough meat to warrant the purchase price. I have no background in coding, and the game didn't punish me for it. It's easy enough to get started with the basics, but also has some room to expand once you've got into your comfort zone, and gives it a surprisingly huge replayability.

Not only that, but there's a decent chunk of content outside the main campaign, as well as a few branching paths that let you get to the crux of the storyline. Huge recommendation from me. I wholeheartedly recommend you check Hacknet out.
Very Addicting game. I feel like a real hacker! I really recommend this game.

Overall, I'm going to rate this game positively. It is one of the most fun games I've played, keeping me actively engaged hours into the night, well after I should have gone to bed. Almost like that classic Civilization one more turn" feel.

Pros: Absolutely a blast to play. It has one of the better story plots to it of games I've had the honor of being a part of.

Con: It took me about five hours to "beat" the game. There is more content that I apparently missed due to my gameplay choices that I can go back and try to find
date: but from start to credits it took me only about five hours."

reviewText:
This game has a lot of HEART.  At it's base, it is a hacker simulation detective style game with a fantastic story.  Everything you need to do is explained or you're given enough hints to figure everything out but if you've ever used a command line or played a text based adventure game you should feel right at home.

Let's go over the high points:
Sound/Music - Amazing, fits the theme, shifts to fit the situation.
Graphics - Visualizers are interesting and background art is cool.  The text is a nice readable font.
Story - Great main story with lots of sidequests.  Events and plot devices are well executed.
Gameplay/Control - Enter text commands or point/click, easy to navigate servers, help system built in for text commands.
Price is VERY reasonable for the quality of this game.

Cons:
If you don't want play a hacker style detective game that makes you feel like a hacker...well I guess you won't like this then!
If you can't read then you won't be able to play the game.  But then you can't read this review either...so this isn't for you.
You aren't playing hacknet yet, you're still reading this review.
I wish the network display was larger...this is a very minor issue.

Other thoughts:
I have finished the game.  I am certainly going to replay it as there are multiple paths and procedurely generated scenarios.  I seriously can't remember the last time I had this much fun or felt this emotional over a game.  I highly recommend you take the journey.
I've only played Hacknet for a short while, and I look forward to spending a few more hours on it, it is an interesting concept and is most like the best hacking simulator out there.
My first impression of this game is that it's definitely immersive and definitely makes you feel like a super secret badass hacker.
My girlfriend saw me playing and thought I was actually hacking other people's computers. 10/10.

I spent 2 hours playing this game... what I thought was going to be just some quick poke around and check it out at 11pm turned into eyes glued to my monitor and its all of a sudden 230 am. Obviously this game is not going to mimic Kali Linux tools or anything like that but the minor detail of simplified .exe
date: s" as they call them is a small factor to the Amazing Storyline and really good twists and turns. When you start getting deep into the game you really find some rewarding moments! Great work dev team. All of the reviews are accurate if you are anyone messing around in programming/network security and you want to brush up your Linux cmd or your a Mr.Robot Fanboy this game is for you. Worth more than $10 look forward to what else this company will put out and/or add to this series.\n\n-CorruptFile105"

Amazing Game! It seemed hard to me when i saw the binary feature but the game eases you into it really well. The plot is amazing and there is alot of extra content and easter eggs that adds hours of playtime. I highly reccomend it!

This game has the potential to be great however there are some major bugs. The gameplay is fun and intuitive. It teaches you everything you need as you go and doesn't overcomplicate things for less tech savvy players. That being said I can't currenty recoment this game due the game breaking bugs. It is possible to reach the final set of missions without all the tools you need to complete them and it’s seemingly impossible to go back and complete the mission that gives you this tool. There is also chance the game will crash if you alt-tab to another window (I’ve also heard that this has caused all saves to be lost but that didn't happened to me). I really hope these issues get fixed in future updates.

What to expect if you're new to this game genreHacknet is a new title in the otherwise stagnant, indie genre of hacking simulation games.
And a fresh breeze it is.

No doubt there is hardly any competition for this kind of quality.
Graphics are amazing, the hacking system introduced is quite good and consistent, it has gigantic potential for expansion that desperately needs to be used, and hopefully will. In it's current shape there might be little room for multiplayer gameplay, because of the game mechanics, but hopefully as the game gets finalized it will be implemented.

The puzzles you have to face are fun to solve and most of the time at medium or easy difficulty level.
Even though the game description provided on Steam might be a little misleading, as to non-holywood hacking style, or minimal hand-holding, the gameplay can be extremely exciting and satisfying.
The thrill of hacking, taking unauthorised control over websites, other web services, or user machines and mobile devices, identity theft or destruction, and constantly racing the trace clock are all very satisfying and will give you an addictive adrenaline rush.

Music is a very proper and enjoyable background for your virtual crimes, not quite something to remember.

The game has too high hardware requirements in my opinion. All in all it is a console based hacking game, and it is barely playable on i5, 4GB, Intel graphics HD4000 Lenovo laptop (12 fps max with too much typing lag!!!)

Finally the 'Uplink vs Hacknet'Many people look up to Hacknet in comparison to Uplink.
Based on my experiences with both titles If you did truly enjoy Uplink, You will be dazzled by Hacknet's modern design. Graphics are eyecandy.
The gameplay itself however, as compared to Uplink I have found to be short (if that can be said - I was unable to finish the game due to numerous bugs [despite 50+hrs in-game]), shallow and at many times unchallenging.
If you can bear with, well kinda outdated graphics and a little clumsy UI, I'd say Uplink offers far greater immersion, much more complex world to explore, more freedom, less hand holding.
Hardware upgrades covering several computer components to your machine, or even different, more upgradable machines (you can create them yourself or download one of many community created ones!!!!), software upgrades that all can be purchased are something you won't find in Hacknet, since finances have been taken out of the picture in the first place. Money earning, stock market participation and manipulation, and banking are all absent in Hacknet. So are LAN networks that pose a sublevel of gameplay in Uplink. Hacknet at this stage of developement also gives you the feeling of being the only web user out there, since only on rare story related events will you ever find logs left by anyone else on any servers (even the public services). Tracing other hackers or users is nearly non existent since the idea of connection bouncing has also been skipped so far. In my opinion, with similar development times of several years for both games, Uplink is a masterpiece bot technically and story-wise, compared to Hacknet.

Final wordsWhatever Hacknet is or will be, I'd say Uplink is worth playing, as the only other hacking game out there with some serious gameplay to this date.
If compatibility issues or the kinda-outdated-look are an obstacle for you playing Uplink, Hacknet will still be a very enjoyable and exciting experience, however I would strongly advise to wait with the purchase until numerous major bugs are addressed and more potential gets released from Hacknet, or you might be facing quite a frustrating struggle with what I can only call a beta version (at best) right now. I have also learned there is a free remake of Uplink to be found out there, I will let you find it yourself tho, since I'd stick with the original version by Introversion Software and support it's makers.
Keep track of Hacknet news and discussion on Steam for a stable version somewhen in the (hopefully) near future.

A great concept let down by a multitude of game breaking bugs. Expect to have to look through the forums for bug fixes and edit your save game to be able to get though the game in its current state.

Summary: Hacknet is a fantastic hacker game; adding a terminal element sets it apart from other games in the genre such as Uplink: Hacker Elite. While in between storyline hacks the game leaves players feeling like their hacks have little reward or purpose, the stunning gameplay, visuals, and story make this game a must buy if you enjoy computers and being stressed out of your mind.

Hacking games such as this are always a thrill, at least in my experience. Nothing gets your heart racing more than a big red countdown as your fingers slip trying to type in a password. Hacknet is a great example of this genre.

Games such as Uplink: Hacker Elite have the player take part in Hollywood hacking"
date: using things like password crackers and dragging bypassers over network elements. While Hacknet it far from realistic hacking

reviewText:
If you liked uplink - you will like this
If you thought that uplink was too hard - you will like this
If you didn't like the concept of uplink - you won't like this

This was a interesting entry into the hacker simulation genre, with great comparisions to the good parts of uplink (another, and much much older hacking sim circa mid 2000s). It does feel lacking in comparison to some features of uplink, such as workstation modification and resource allocation. What this game misses on those fronts - it makes up for on the story aspect. The connecting story is compelling enough to warrent a play through, and to provide motivation to successfully complete a hack

Even in failure this game gives you an opportunity to improve your skills by giving you a last ditch chance to hack your way out of your situation.

Highly recommend this game as an entry into the hacker simulation genre - however if you have played others I would recommend looking at uplink, as this game is not overly complicated.

This game is honestly one of the best games I have played. Hacknet is a hacking simulator which may or may not be realistic, I am not a hacker or very good with computers so I would not know but without a doubt it's worth every penny of those $10.00. The game focuses on you as the main character who is suddenly emailed by a enigmatic hacker by the name of bit who teaches you his techniques which launchs off your career as a hacker. As the game goes on you will later be approached by more and more hackers and hacker organizations. One thing I find so enjoyable is the problem solving aspect, sure plenty of the game is just using the tools at your disposal to get into this system or to hack that site but at times your knowledge of the system and the games mechanics will be put to the test. If you have any chance of beating this game you need to be smart, creative, quick to react, and you cannot break under pressure because this game can get pretty intense. Another great aspect of this game it the difficulty. At first it's relatively easy but as time goes on you will begin to notice how this game is unforgiving when you screw up. Not kidding, it's brutal here dude. The game will have multiple instances where a rival hacker is at your throat or when you have a trace running on you and you need to open and hack the ports as fast as possible to become an admin and stop the trace. Sometimes it's going to look bleak but it is soooooo satisfying when you hack the system with seconds to spare and sooooo disapointing when you fail and are wacked over the nose as a result. That does not mean this game is without problems. For one even though the format of the game is its greatest strength it also can be its greatest weakness mainly due to the fact that it is not a very engaging experience and requires you to try your best to stay on top of actually playing the game. The narrative is good without a doubt but it also can get dull at times and even kind of confusing. It's more of a mystery of trying to figure out what happened to Bit but it seems as if they tried to squeez in more and though for the most part the game flows beautifully at times it does get a little cramped. I also have a personal complaint, every time I start the game, even though my profile is still their, it starts me off at the beggining. I don't know if this is supposed to happen or not but I would assume not. I continue trying to find a solution but otherwise I have to beat the game in one consistan run which is kind of erritating but still fun. overally solid 8.5/10, worth buying.

Frickin Amazing

Hacknet, Uplink's spiritual successor.

Developed by a one-man studio called Team Fractal Alligator, Hacknet is a terminal-based game that implements real UNIX codes and commands to bypass and/or shutdown firewalls, proxys, ports, etc., to gain access to other peoples' computers and eOS devices (game's parody of smartphones) for their information or information in general and retype false info for a cilent to help him, steal the infomation and expose it to light, or destroy the user's computer server.

The story for me so far is surpisingly good. To avoid spoilers, I'll keep it short. It involves a notorius hacker named Bit. He fails to reconnect to his system for 14 days, his failsafe kicks in, sending instructions in automated emails to you. It's up to you to find out why.

You can get jobs from different entites, such as CSEC, to receive hack codes and malware injectors to help you along your cyber hacking adventure. Sadly, unlike Uplink, you don't earn money and you can't upgrade your computer, RAM, CPU, etc.

Lots of little secrets here and there, some computers have little chat logs from other users for a fun read. The music is good, nice tempo beat to it.

Overall, it's a fun terminal-based hackers game with a modern day retouch.

From all of the hacking games.... this game is the best one so far. The story line keeps you interested in keep playing.. the puzzles are not as too easy not too hard to solve.\n\n9.5/10 Satisfaction :)

Hacknet is a game in which you do various tasks for various people for various reasons. You delete files, fetch passwords, etc. See it as a puzzle game, of sorts.

reviewText:
Hacknet is a hacking simulation in the vein of Introversion's fantastic Uplink. It provides the player a virtual OS from which to interact with 'nodes' dotted around the map. Each node represents a computer system which can be approached using the software and hardware knowledge you accumulate throughout the game. Pretty simple stuff on the surface, but Hacknet is a fantastically well-designed story-driven experience, with considerable replay value which will only continue to grow as new content is invariably released.

This game deserves praise for it's graphics, in that they perfectly fit the tone of the game. In most other game genres we typically see a push toward more cutting-edge photo-realism, but here we have a clean, crisp environment that doesn't over-burden or confuse the player with menus and tedious repetitive interaction. Praise is also due to the sound design in this title. The music is, again, a perfect fit for the game's tone. Orchesteral strings move to thumping bass adding a sense of pressure and drive that has kept me going back just for the music.


There are some problems with this game however. Some people will say these aren't problems as such, more personal gripes, but take them however you wish.

1. It's short. Like really short. With no experience whatsoever, my first run was just under 3 hours from start to finish, completing every avaliable mission in the game aside from 'Junebug' which was bugged at the time. Hopefully, more content will be added soon, and the ability to open story creation to the community is an exciting prospect shound it be considered.

2. It's easy. The learning curve is pretty shallow, with a few basic commands covering every action you will be performing. Once you have got launching cracks using the TAB key down to a fine art, you can smash through any security in next to no time.

3. No Upgrade abilities. A key component of every computer interface is the hardware it's connected to, and in a game setting the ability to upgrade and customise that hardware is a given. There is no such system here. The only resource you have is RAM, which is set throughout the game and cannot be improved upon. This does give the game a streamlined feel, but I would still rather have an functioning economy and avenues to explore with my earnings.

Overall, I think Hacknet deserves your time if you enjoy the genre. If you do enjoy this quite esoteric game style, then you've no doubt played the alternatives. On balance, I would say that Onlink, the fan-made re-write of Uplink is the superior game in this category still. It is a longer, more challenging experience. That being said, with expansion and dedication, Hacknet will become the standard by which all other hacking simulation games will be judged. We should all help it get there, and enjoy the rewards when they come.

Buy it.

This game is very different from what I've played before. Since the game is so different from all the others I've played it really caught my attention.

I found the game short after I started watching a new TV-series, Mr Robot. After the first two episodes I was hooked, so I looked around here on Steam for some new hacking games and suddenly I found this little gem. I've had some experience with running a Linux server, so all the server commands in the game was not so new to me... and made my experience much better.

The game itself has some bugs when going through your first playthrough, so if you are considering buying this now(Aug.2015), I suggest you look at some guides or the forums to see how to do the first playthrough without any hassle. That was the only downside for me.

The story in the game isn't all that interesting, but it gives your actions meaning... and that makes the game much more fun! The way the game starts feels like a fresh boot on a new computer(if it had any tutorials tho).

I really hope they add some kind of DLC, because this game have great potential and I would definitly play it!

UPDATE - A couple of days after I post this review, the developer announces that he patched the bug that made the game impossible to complete. While another bug does exist at present (where if you do not accept the Junebug mission in time, you lose the opportunity to continue with the main story), it is possible to work around this by reloading an old save.

Upon reaching the end of the game, I am absolutely convinced that this game is one of (if not) the best hacking simulators on the market. The final mission in the game is so intense. I had to do it in several parts and my heart was racing each time I started it. There was nothing I could suggest to make the gameplay itself any better. Maybe adding in more missions to give it some replayability and a bit more freedom to go off and hack to your hearts content for good or for evil. However, that could be a DLC pack and can easily be added in. As the game stands, it deserves an 8/10, purely because it's still not perfect in terms of the bugs. However, they should be fixed soon given the dedication the dev has with this game.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Let me be perfectly clear with this before you read any further. I LOVE Hacknet. It's a fantastic game and is definitely better than Uplink by a mile. The use of real computer commands makes it feel much more realistic and the storyline is pretty awesome to boot. Plus, the time limit you have when a trace counter starts rapidly going down and you're waiting for the password crack to finish so you can intercept the trace creates one heck of an adrenaline rush.

However I cannot recommend it as it is now. There is a single bug I have encountered that makes the game impossible to complete. I will try to avoid giving away any spoilers, so this will be a bit vague. Later in game you are required to take on a mission that is part of the main storyline. However, you do not choose when this mission comes to you. It is automatically sent to you in an email and I'm not 100% sure what the criteria is for it appearing. To complete it, you need an .exe file used to crack a specific port which is only available by taking on a side mission. However, this mission is locked and once again, I do not know what the criteria is to unlock it. So I tried to take on the other available missions in an attempt to unlock the one I needed. In order to do this, you must abort the main storyline mission. Aborting a mission means you can NEVER attempt it again, making it impossible to continue with the main storyline. While I discovered it is possible to obtain the .exe without the mission, following an online walkthrough to obtain the information needed to get it instead of getting it in game feels wrong on so many levels, especially since it's deeply hidden within this seemingly permanently locked mission.

So at this time, I can't recommend it. The game is good, but I haven't been able to finish it because of this bug. The developer seems to be quite willing to take feedback and work on it so if you're reading this, I eagerly await a patch for this game. I can't wait to finish it.

A short but sweet homage to Uplink: Hacker Elite. While the game itself is fun, the story progress (and thus, the whole savegame) can be destroyed too easily by deleting important files. For example, various contracts can only be fulfilled by answering specific mails, if you delete those, you cannot proceed (some mails state that you have to reply, but some don't even if you have to).

While it may be overreach to say Hacknet is revolutionary or groundbreakingly-original, it is a modernisation of a neglected and important genre. Its production has been with such passion that you will find yourself engrossed as a character, amidst a lightweight but visually enthralling presentation, longing for more after you've done all that you can. The experience is well worth the low cost of admission. Hopefully the developer will expand on this venture if they have found it successful. Future generations of gamers desperately need more like this.

Pros:
Excellent gameplay (both graphical and command-line based)
Great music
Story line is good
Plenty of hints and tips for newbs
Best visuals and effects for a hacker simulator game

Cons:
Some tasks are too easy (if you are not computer literate)
No system upgrades
No multiplayer

As an update I would like to see the following:

Online Multiplayer
- Free for all
- Co-op (Verse AI or team up with a friend to accomplish tasks)
- Host and join hacker groups

Different game modes
- Sandbox
- Hardcore (less trace time, more firewalls, proxies, encrypted data)

More software, tools, aggressive hackers, banks, governments, top secret organizations. Webcam screenshots or video cam footage, something to keep the game interesting. Contracts to blackmail people, live news video footages that shows your aftermath or damage to a business.

Overall, this is game is must have for any computer enthusist or anyone who has played Uplink.

reviewText: This is probably one of the most entertaining games I have played in awhile. I have always been a sucker for the hacking type games since Uplink was released. This game had me so engrossed with the way it wraps the HacknetOS that I had a slight panic when I was nearly caught on a contract and had to scramble to reset my IP at the ISP mainframe.\n\nIt can get a little repetitive after you figure out a solid routine to break in to a few systems but still extremely fun for something different than the FPS, Sidescroll, Survival and RTS standards out there.

This is an amazing game. It's completely reliant on reading a lot of text, but it fits in with the hacker-working-from-their-terminal kind of narrative the story thrusts you into. The soundtrack is a perfect mix of chill hacker music that helps immerse you into all the commands you're going to be throwing at servers as you attempt to break in. What's particularly interesting is that the game uses several true linux commands for many of the common functions (ls, rm, scp) that really make it feel like a real operating system you're using to break into systems around the internet.\n\nOn the minus side, it's kind of easy to get caught up in rushing through systems without really stopping to poke around. With the threat of active security features giving a sense of urgency to complete my tasks and move on, I can't help but feel like I missed out on files I should have been reading that contacts in the game would reference after I completed objectives and progressed the story. Still, it seems like a rather authentic hacking simulator, making use of that thrilling text-based console the media associates so dearly with hacker-types, and turning it into the backbone of an enjoyable game.

Really impressed! Having played Uplink and the like, I've fallen in love with this game which is much more realistic and somehow less cumbersome at the same time. A lot of old cliches are simplified down, you get a 99sec timer instead of repetitively bouncing connections around a map. You can remove all log files with a single command instead of running through each one with a log deleter and worrying about leaving suspicious deletions.\n\nSo what replaces all this? An updated lite version of Uplink.
Hacknet is amazing, but what keeps it from topping Uplink is that it has less features and flexibility.

Disclaimer: I've not yet completed the entire game. But based on a wild experience I've had with it, I felt prompted to write the review.

If you played Uplink, this is basically an updated version of the game.  Focused on command consoles, IP, file retrieval/removal all in a neat little interface.

It takes some of the very same queues from Uplink in its story, as you investigate about a hacker named Bit.

Pros:
Authentic feel
Challenging yet very satisfying
Outstanding music
Cons:
No money system. The fun part of Uplink was going off on the side and robbing banks wirelessly, and using the money to build an unstoppable system, and simply feeling rewarded for your contracts.
No hardware to upgrade.
Tutorials and in-game info isn't always clear. I know its not supposed to hand-hold. But it feels like many commands are left out, as well as some contracts aren't clear about what they want sometimes. The explanation of Shells and Trapping are complete garbage. That needs to be fixed.
Lack of freedom. Uplink had a lot more freedom in becoming a white hat, black hat, or grey hat.  Also had more in the way of non-linear gameplay choices.
Lack of freedom in file editing. In uplink you could change log files, and put someone elses IP in place of your own... Leading to hilarious results as you pin your hacks on someone else.
What's awesome: Unlike Uplink, it gives you a chance at redemption if you fail some missings, and even a chance at revenge.

What's not awesome: The very linear gameplay.

One major letdown : No sandbox mode/options.

Overall: Some glaring bad decisions aside, it is a great game. It tense, it makes you feel like a hacker, it has some great polish, and all this for the price its asking is a no brainer. It's a very decent game, but it COULD have been great.  Still waiting for the real Uplink 2 to stand up.

I've just finished Hacknet, and as you can tell by my total playtime (which also includes a profile I didn't quite complete), it's not a very long game. However, I'm quite sure that you will love every minute of it.

I'm not entirely sure how this game stacks up if you just want another Uplink (I haven't played that particular game), but there are other reviews that focus on that. What I can tell you is that this game is a stylish, sleek, and very impressive hacking simulator. The plot is woven very well into the game, and there are easter eggs and hidden things aplenty. I made it a point to look at every IRC archive on every computer I hacked, because I'd be laughing even while they traced my IP address.

The game's solution to everything is elegant and new; nothing feels like a tired concept. The game is just long enough to be as impressive as possible with all of its assets.

On the negative side, the slightly buggy nature of the game is where the indie nature really shows. My first playthrough went well enough until I was hit with a progression-ending bug that I didn't realize until I had actually made progress into a hidden sidequest. From then on, I was a little bit afraid to explore and screw around in case I got hit with another glitch. An option to load from saves wouldn't be amiss, but I'm sure people would use it to save-scum (and unfortunately miss one of Hacknet's coolest features: attempting to forcibly reset your IP address just after a trace has reached your computer, which adds to the game's tension).

Some objectives and game aspects are a little unclear, especially when worded in the game's cool cyber-security lingo (which actually adds to the charm to some extent). For instance, there's only a small sliver of documentation about a considerably-important yet optional feature: setting up proxies as traps" to be sprung if a trace is about to reach you
date: which overloads your computer but stops the trace from doing any lasting damage. Experimenting is rendered difficult due to the fear of bugs as above - again
recommended: some sort of feature to load a session might help.\n\nHowever
hoursPlayed: above all
voteText: you will find that Hacknet is well worth your time and $10 (or $8 if you buy during this Steam sale)
helpfulPercent: because - be honest with yourself - you're looking into Hacknet to feel like a Hollywood Hacker
votesHelpful: and that's exactly what this game makes you feel like."

Great Game

I actually never finished uplink. After hours and hours, I grew tired of it. This game, however, is different. Its user interface is more intuitive and there is much less grinding to get to the story.

There are some drawbacks, however:
- the game requires a significant amount of computer resources, somewhat astonishing for a game that mainly lives off its command line interface.
- Every modern command line interface is better than this one. Tab completion works, but not always. Wildcards work, but only if they're alone on their line.

On the other hand, this game shows many aspects of real hacking, and the software is much better than most real hacker tools I've seen. Of course, the technical details are oversimplified. But the methods used (later in the game, in particular) are actually quite similar to what real hackers do when taking over large networks.

I would like to love Hacknet but I ultimately find it underwhelming. The gameplay is nothing really exciting, it's more of a mechanical matter of using the appropriate tool for each situation (use the SSH cracker to crack open a SSH port, etc.). Really excellent text driven hacking game, using real unix commands to navigate the different server nodes the game has a pretty decent story with a good amount of clue finding and investigation to solve the challenges to progress.  The game has some hidden secrets which means an extra partial playthrough is needed if you want all the achievements.

The challenges never get too frustratingly difficult but can sometimes be tough especially when working against a trace clock.

The only negative i can really say about theg ame is that the UI could be better if you were allowed to move elements around yourself, the NetMap for example cannot be zoomed or resized and towards the end of the game its gets quite busy with the different nodes so it can be difficult to find were you are and what you need to connect to.

The game on face value might not appeal to people who are not interested in IT or hacking which is a shame as the game is actually a really good puzzle game outside of the interface/text driven elements.

Overall i have massively enjoyed playing this game, i would love to see the game developed further maybe with additional DLC or even steam workshop integration were we could create our own challenge scenarios.

First things first, I loved the slick layout and visuals Hacknet plays quite nicely.  Music is pretty damn good too!

At first I really liked Hacknet as it feels like what Uplink should be in the modern gaming age.  You get cool looking interfaces, some psuedo-unix commands and maniplulations and a feeling of pressure as you hack your way past traces and logs.  However, thats where it falls apart a little.  You realise that logs are redundant and apart from an active trace when hacking some systems there are no repercussions to breaking log chains.  Except for one scripted event you dont need to worry about the men in black knocking on your door.  It was this attention to detail and consequnce that, in my opinion, gave Uplink its amazing gameplay.  I felt like the game needed that next level of complexity and difficulty to really come of age.

The major thumbs down however is game breaking bugs.  At time of writing this review there is at least one huge bug that is preventing the game being completed.  An attempt at fixing the bug was done but it did not solve the problem.  Cudos for the Developer at rushing to solve the issue but after one attempted patch there has been no communication on the status of the bug for about a month now.

Bottomline.  Its a fun little game but becomes one dimentional and easy once you realise there is no real way to lose apart from letting an active hack trace get you but even that is easily bypassed with one click or command.  The killer at this stage is bugs and more bugs.  I hope the game gets fixed and expanded, it could be a very nice game one day.


UPDATE:  The major bug has been fixed and I was able to finish the game.  Thanks to the Dev for fixing that up.
I have left my recommendation as negatvie which I am sad about as the game is pretty good.  The problem still is that its too easy once you realise there arent any repurcussions to not covering your tracks.  A little more depth would make this game a killer title!
AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA ITS SO GOOOD AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

I've replayed it quite a few times (as in up-to-game-breaking-bug, uninstall, check back, restart, next bug...), so I can also vouch for its immense replayability! Furthermore, now I actually could play it through, and the ending is surprisingly heavily touching; I won't spoil how so, but I take it as a proof of how immersed into that game setting I was/am :)

The game is fun, but there are many bugs in the end game,
Many players, including me, cannot past some missions of the end game, what is really frustrating.
There are some workarounds, including changing the save game (xml), but support in Steam Community is not very clear.

It also have lots of save problems. This is really a bad thing...

See the list of open bugs in Community Forum, if Complete Bit Investigation  is still open, it is a bad sign.

Message for an incompleted mission also give you no hint on how to go on.
You must play it with a notebook or you probably will forget things. The game would be better with virtual notebook.

Some missions in the middle game can be skipped, however they provide necessary tools for the end game.

I would recommend the game if it worked smoothly, but it seems that it was launched a bit early.

(As of version 4.017 - on 2016-01-09)

A short, but very sweet, hacking simulator similar to the classic Uplink.  However, Hacknet is much more story-focused and linear, and is closer to being real" in that you spend a lot of playing time using a UNIX-like command line.  Rock Paper Shotgun called the game more a work of Interactive Fiction than an open hacking sim
date:
and they're pretty much right.

+ Nice use of a faux command-line making you feel l33t instead of just punching "hack" buttons on a UI
+ Straightforward challenges mixed up with a few head scratchers requiring diligent exploration of server contents
+ Great presentation and ease of use
+ Plenty of atmosphere
+ Decent enough story
recommended:
if a bit predictable once the (few) major players come on the scene
+ Doesn't overstay its welcome with grind

- No real replayability"

Was hacking into a system when I started to get traced, but kept going anyways trying to beat the clock. Found the data, copied it to my system, deleted it from theirs, and covered my tracks. Trace timer got to 2 seconds, and I disconnected, in the clear.

But I wasn't. They started intruding my system, tried to use shells to trap the counterhack. Didn't work. Panicked. Could only remember one command: forkbomb. Typed it in.

Immediately blue screened in the game, and breathed a sigh of relief.

In-game computer rebooted and I discovered I had deleted a vital .sys file. Now I'm stuck trying to figure out how to recover my OS in the game.

10/10 would blue screen again

Fantastic design and story allowed me to truly feel I was hacker. An immersive game that is not afraid to throw users into the deep end with challenging puzzles and dynamic story telling. This is a must have for any networking enthusiast.

Anyone interested in simulation games, and who loves speed-typing under stress, should definitely pick this one up. I'm not too far along in the game as of yet, but so far the story is intriguing and nicely paced. The stress element is definitely helping me practice how accurate my typing is.

If there were extra missions or DLC, I'd get that in a heartbeat. Just... get this game. You won't be disappointed.\n\nAlso... 11/10 would get hacked by an NPC again...

My job has me working on routers and switches and so I find myself loving CLI. This game combines CLI with a visual interface for conveniece which makes it a lot more friendly and visually appealling as a game. Even getting past little challenges felt extremely rewarding for me. I'm no hacker but this game definitely convices you into feeling like you are and with actual IT knowledge seeing things like SSH and FTP ports takes my knowledge and makes it feel just a little more real. HELL YEAH guys. You're doing it right.
